question.title: Why does this not sort the list?

node.contents: `Arrays.sort(word.toCharArray());` manipulate the `char[]`, basically changing the word (not the String object, the word stored in your `char[]`). I am not sure I am following what are you after.

astNode.text: `Arrays.sort(word.toCharArray());` manipulate the `char[]`, basically changing the word (not the String object, the word stored in your `char[]`). I am not sure I am following what are you after.

node.contents: Your commented out code seems to be the right approach: get the char[] from the string. Then, sort it. Then, add that to your sortedWords[]. Otherwise, the word.toCharArray() is creating an array that you sort. Then, you're ignoring it and creating a brand new charArray()from your string.

astNode.text: Your commented out code seems to be the right approach: get the char[] from the string. Then, sort it. Then, add that to your sortedWords[]. Otherwise, the word.toCharArray() is creating an array that you sort. Then, you're ignoring it and creating a brand new charArray()from your string.

node.contents: Is the confusion coming from the fact that `toCharArray` isn't returning a reference to some already existing object?

astNode.text: Is the confusion coming from the fact that `toCharArray` isn't returning a reference to some already existing object?

node.contents: @DariusX. Thank you; I was just confused with how the reference would work. That makes sense. I thought by invoking sort on the word's char array, the word's char array would then be sorted for eternity.

node.contents: String is a special Object, mostly in that it's immutable.

node.contents: I was able to fix it by actually creating a new ArrayList, with each element being a char array, by I would've thought I had the reference of each elements char array, and by sorting it and adding it to a new list, that each element would be a sorted char array. Just to improve my conceptual understanding, please shed some light. Thanks

node.contents: Suppose I have a a list of words, = "Stack", "Mack", in an ArrayList named words, I want to sort each element of words alphabetically, i.e element 0 of sortedWords should be ackSt, etc. I know how to do this, but I was surprised as to how I couldn't do it by pointing to it.

elements.contents: ArrayList<ArrayList<String>> groupedAnagrams = new ArrayList<>(); ArrayList<char[]> sortedWords = new ArrayList<>(); for(String word : words){ //char[] sortedWord = word.toCharArray(); Arrays.sort(word.toCharArray()); sortedWords.add(word.toCharArray()); }

node.contents: Please have a look at source code of String#toCharArray():

astNode.text: Please have a look at source code of String#toCharArray():

elements.contents: /** * Converts this string to a new character array. * * @return a newly allocated character array whose length is the length * of this string and whose contents are initialized to contain * the character sequence represented by this string. */ public char[] toCharArray() { char result[] = new char[count]; getChars(0, count, result, 0); return result; }

fragments.text: /** * Converts this string to a new character array. * * @return a newly allocated character array whose length is the length * of this string and whose contents are initialized to contain * the character sequence represented by this string. */

units.rawText: /** * Converts this string to a new character array. * * @return a newly allocated character array whose length is the length * of this string and whose contents are initialized to contain * the character sequence represented by this string. */ public char[] toCharArray() { char result[] = new char[count]; getChars(0, count, result, 0); return result; }

node.contents: Every time it returns you a new char[].

astNode.text: Every time it returns you a new char[].

node.contents: You haven't stored the returned array hence the sorting result has been lost after sorting.

astNode.text: You haven't stored the returned array hence the sorting result has been lost after sorting.

node.contents: `Arrays.sort` is a void method, you cannot assign back the result of the sort to a char array.

astNode.text: `Arrays.sort` is a void method, you cannot assign back the result of the sort to a char array.
